posts.name: garyk
posts.cooked:
I learned from a UC Santa Cruz CS professor that the White House Office of the National Cyber Director (ONCD) has discouraged the use of C and C++, instead recommending memory-safe programming languages, e.g. Java, Rust, Python, …

The long version from ONCD: https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2024/02/Final-ONCD-Technical-Report.pdf

A good distillation: https://www.tomshardware.com/software/security-software/white-house-urges-developers-to-avoid-c-and-c-use-memory-safe-programming-languages

Related: https://media.defense.gov/2023/Apr/27/2003210083/-1/-1/0/CSI_SOFTWARE_MEMORY_SAFETY_V1.1.PDF

link_counts.title: White House urges developers to avoid C and C++, use 'memory-safe' programming languages | Tom's Hardware

posts.name: Saathvik
posts.cooked: This is gonna do basically nothing. The world runs on C and the white house really can’t change that.

posts.name: garyk
posts.cooked: Regardless of what your favorite programming language might be, this announcement is good to know for your programming internship interviews and/or college applications.

Good luck writing operating systems in Python…

Snark aside - As someone that’s written a LOT of professional C and C++ code, from a memory perspective you have to know what you are doing. A lot of buffer overruns which have led to security issues are the result of developers using functions like strcpy() in correctly.   However SOMEONE has to deal with memory. Compilers, Operating Systems, Device drivers are all examples of applications where that needs to happen. For that you need languages with low level access like C,C++, and Assembler to do that stuff quickly.

It’s a tool - and like any tool you pick the right one for the job.

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked: lmao C and C++ aren’t going anywhere, no one has the time or expertise to rewrite something like the linux kernel in another language, and even if it was plausible why . The resources could be better spent on many other things.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
LPryor:

A lot of buffer overruns which have led to security issues are the result of developers using functions like strcpy() in correctly. However SOMEONE has to deal with memory. Compilers, Operating Systems, Device drivers are all examples of applications where that needs to happen. For that you need languages with low level access like C,C++, and Assembler to do that stuff quickly.

I agree on the necessity for languages in that niche, but we need to improve the languages and tooling so mistakes are harder to make and easier to catch. C is a simple language, but writing correct code in it can be complex, and while it’s a great language for perfect programmers, I’ve yet to meet one. Our tools can and should help us more.

Even if we did fix the language and tooling issues though, that still doesn’t save us from logic errors (another large class of CVEs). The processes used to design, implement, and validate safety-critical software are even more important than the languages and tools themselves; we have to assume bugs will happen, so the goal is to minimize them as well as their negative impact when they’re hit. In my opinion, the software industry needs to focus on improving their processes, because the fast-and-loose approach used so far isn’t good enough, and it’s why regulators started paying more attention.

Here’s a relevant panel from CppCon that discusses this stuff:

calcmogul:

while it’s a great language for perfect programmers, I’ve yet to meet one.

Hi, my name’s Chris.

All joking aside, there are applications where C/C++ will be the only logical choice, and this isn’t going to change any time soon. Nobody is writing an operating system or a device driver completely in Java.  I was just talking with an engineer who was brushing up on his COBOL skills for a new job assignment, so…

C is Dead! Long Live C!

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
brainiac:

The world runs on C and the white house really can’t change that.

This has been true ever since someone reprogrammed the last GOTO statement from the last FORTRAN subroutine.

calcmogul:

I agree on the necessity for languages in that niche, but we need to improve the languages and tooling so mistakes are harder to make and easier to catch. C is a simple language, but writing correct code in it can be complex, and while it’s a great language for perfect programmers, I’ve yet to meet one. Our tools can and should help us more.

Congratulations you’ve met your first perfect programmer…. J/K. I agree that it can be difficult to use low level languages for complex projects… and add in the complexities of networking, etc and it can get worst.

But as I advised Purdue years ago as a Microsoft employee…you just can’t replace low level languages with the high level stuff because it’s in fashion. someone has to deal with memory.

Now given the speed of today’s computers, interpreted and high level languages are fine for a lot of solutions.

I agree on tooling and I see scenarios where AI helps write low level functions as well as test cases to look for interaction issues. Although there is a danger that machine authored code may be hard to read, and that people won’t understand how the code works. The latter being an issue in that I don’t believe in using code you don’t understand.

Again I think for the average application, the high level stuff is fine. On a daily basis I personally prefer c# for quick and dirty work. However I’ve worked on operating systems(literally windows), low level mobile applications, dozens of commercial video games… the niche of high performance applications is quite large and will always be necessary.  We don’t need for every app to be C and C++ but we DO need the kinds of students who read Chief Delphi to learn those languages, have that tool in their belt, and know when they should use it.

Hence my real point. Let’s not chase our young software engineers away from this stuff. Learn c,c++, assembler…. Don’t run away from memory management. Understand EVERYTHING that’s going on under the hood

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
There’s a bit of background here: the US has a really big cybersecurity problem and  the various organs of the US government have been using whatever levers they have available to help solve that problem, with mixed success.  The federal government’s reach varies a lot by industry, so some areas (e.g. banking) are in much better shape than others (e.g. local water systems).

One place currently being considered for new regulations/legislation is to make software publishers responsible for negligent coding practices that create security vulnerabilities.   And, this action by the White House may help define what “negligent coding practices” ARE.   So, right now, this is just the White House’s opinion.  But, consider the following from some future case:

Plaintiff’s counsel:  “[…]  So, the program was able to write more bytes to the stack than you had originally intended, overwriting the return address.  Is that correct?”

Programmer: “Yes, that’s basically it”

Plaintiff’s counsel:  “Don’t programming languages prevent you from doing that ?”

Programmer: “Well, some do, but we programmed this in C and C does not prevent that.”

Plaintiff’s counsel: “Why did you choose to program in C?”

Programmer: “I don’t know.  It’s what we always do.”

Plaintiff’s counsel: “Could you have written a program to do the same thing in Rust?”

Programmer:  “Sure, I suppose.”

Plaintiff’s counsel: “And, if you had written it in Rust, would this error have been possible?”

Programmer:  “no.”

Plaintiff’s counsel: “Are you aware that the ONCD has advised against using C because of this sort of memory problem?”

Programmer: “Yes”

Plaintiff’s counsel: “If you had followed that advice, would this massive security breach that cost my client $100M have happened?”

Programmer: “No.”

No main stream programming language is going to disappear over night.

Back in the day… I learn Basic, Fortran, Pascal, and Cobalt.  All have there places.  I am sure there are some pretty hefty systems somewhere still using these.  Today I use none of them directly but I must keep a small group of DOS computers ready to interact with DOS specific software and very old hardware that helps keep the world running.  (Don’t for get your paper tape with your operating software on it. ;))

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
CEF:

Plaintiff’s counsel: “Why did you choose to program in C?”

Programmer: “I don’t know. It’s what we always do.”

it is very likely that the Programmer had no authority to select the programming language.  Plaintiff’s counsel is laying groundwork to find out who did – likely the next witness, or one after that.  Programmer may not get off scot-free, but he won’t be tossed under the bus.  There’s a CTO lurking somewhere in this case.

It’s sad to see the White House hating on languages just because they’re harder. C/C++ makes up so much of our current infrastructure, and C++ in particular combines high level abstractions with lower level access rather well in my opinion. As someone who loves knowing how stuff works and such, I may be biased, but a lot of the problems aren’t with the languages, but with how they’re used. Testing for things like buffer overflows can be automated, and guidelines can be written to keep people from making stupid mistakes as opposed to trying to rewrite the world in Rust. I love rust as a language, but sometimes lower level access is needed. As @LPryor said, knowing how things work is definitely important either way, and redesigning everything we write to depend on some compiler written by one dead guy who knew how it worked is definitely bad. People are seeing how easy it is to write a python script or ask ChatGPT how to write software, but not knowing how python works or what ChatGPT is telling you to compile can be dangerous, especially if we try to move society as a whole into ignorance. All this is not to say that lower level languages are “better” by any means, but simply that they have modern use cases too, contrary to what the White House seems to be implying.

As far as FIRST is concerned, I have a similar opinion. Teams using python have a shorter dev time and easier time making things work, but at the highest levels, teams that use c++ can have more control over what they do.

In summary, moving away from lower level languages (c/c++/asm) is dangerous, as knowing why what you’re programming works and what the code is doing to your computer is beneficial. However, that doesn’t mean that all current c/c++ usages are justified, and using a simpler language when the speed, performance, and control losses are negligible is definitely optimal for development time, simplicity, and robustness.

posts.name: Justin Tervay
posts.cooked:
brainiac:

This is gonna do basically nothing. The world runs on C and the white house really can’t change that.

You’re missing the point. To quote the original 19 page statement:

White House:

Building new products and migrating high-impact legacy code to memory safe programming languages can significantly reduce the prevalence of memory safety vulnerabilities throughout the digital ecosystem.[xi]

To be sure, there are no one-size-fits-all solutions in cybersecurity, and using a memory safe programming language cannot eliminate every cybersecurity risk. However, it is a substantial, additional step technology manufacturers can take toward the elimination of broad categories of software vulnerabilities.

…

These efforts will be bold, long-term endeavors that require sustained focus and prioritization. Now is the time to begin this work.

[xi] Project Zero: The More You Know, The More You Know You Don’t Know

This isn’t a “law.” The White House is not changing it themselves. They are publicly identifying a large mass of security problems that tend to occur due to the same problem - memory mismanagement. One remedy for this class of problem - which will not remedy every problem - is by having computers manage memory themselves (such as ownership at compile time [Rust or Zig] or through runtime memory allocation [Java]).

Also, it can change: Linux and Fuchsia are both low-level projects incorporating Rust. No, Linux doesn’t have a lot of Rust right now, but it’s more Rust than it was 5 years ago.

veg:

Nobody is writing an operating system or a device driver completely in Java.

No, but you can in Rust or Zig … or even Ada .

The White House isn’t saying to write an OS in Java.

7dblackhole:

just because they’re harder

This is not at all the point of the post nor the intended message. It’s so far off course that I’m not sure if you read any of the 19 page statement.
